> As we walked through Fullerton’s downtown, Weev told me about his day — he’d lost $10,000 on the commodities market, he claimed — and summarized his philosophy of “global ruin.” “We are headed for a Malthusian crisis,” he said, with professorial confidence. “Plankton levels are dropping. Bees are dying. There are tortilla riots in Mexico, the highest wheat prices in 30-odd years.” He paused. “The question we have to answer is: How do we kill four of the world’s six billion people in the most just way possible?” He seemed excited to have said this aloud.

Author: gnaritas
Content:
"Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu"

Ah, see, that's what I meant by being a means, a sport is and end and something fun in itself where the getting in shape is a side effect. When I say working out, I'm specifically talking about pumping iron in a gym. Yes I'm a programmer, so my definition isn't so much narrow as it is precise, what can I say; that's how we are. Playing a sport isn't working out, it's playing a sport; that it happens to work you out is not the main point merely a nice benefit. Where I live, it's 115 degrees outside, working up a sweat is the last thing I want to do, I spend much of my time trying to stop sweating!

"Last week, I wondered if I could do five reps of five set of Clean & Press at 185 pounds."

Yes, but can you wonder that a few times a week on a regular basis and continue to get any thrill or sense of accomplishment out of it. Performance are only motivating when you're trying to improve your performance, but that can't go on forever, at some point you just want to maintain and it's the maintaining, at a gym, that's boring as fuck.

I agree you have to find something fun to do that works you out as a side effect, like "Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu", which is my whole point. Pumping iron in the gym, in the long term, is boring as fuck, no matter how you slice it.

I haven't found my "something fun" yet, maybe I will someday, but good for you that you have.

Author: greyman
Content:
Yes, the conditions are comparable for those citizens, who were labeled as enemies of the regime. I don't know what you will accept as an evidence, but here are a few links:

http://laogai.org - research of the laogai, so called "Chinese gulags". China has more than 1,000 of them.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falun_Gong_and_live_organ_harve... - Organ harvesting from living people

There are also other reports by United Nations or Amnesty international about that.

Author: unohoo
Title: Ask PG: Does YC review single founder applications?
Content:
PG,

As part of the YC application, I noticed a question asking if I'm the only founder. The answer to that is,unfortunately, yes.

My question is - in that scenario, should I even submit the YC application ? Will it be reviewed ? The rest of the questions that are grouped with this one give me an impression that (a) its unlikely to be reviewed or (b)rejected from get go.

thanks.

PS: I have read your essay about the whys of having a co-founder. And I agree. Its just that I havent found a worthy co-founder yet.

Author: wtrk
Content:
The Soviet regime ran a large system of forced labor camps. China currently runs a large system of forced labor camps. Horrible human rights violations occurred under the Soviet system and are currently occurring in China.

Here's a recent, quite representative, example of the sort of thing that can happen to someone in China:

"Chinese teacher sent to labour camp for earthquake photos" http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jul/30/chinaearthquake....

Excerpt:

  A Chinese teacher has been sent to a labour camp over his   
  internet photographs of schools that collapsed in the 
  Sichuan earthquake, a rights group said today.

  Liu Shaokun was ordered to serve a year of "re-education   
  through labour", according to Human Rights in China. The 
  system does not require a formal charge or criminal trial 
  and there is no appeal.

Author: ars
Content:
No it doesn't, sunlight has nothing to do with it (using light to lyse (photolyse?) water would be cool, but they aren't). But thank you for the link, it makes more sense then the other one.

In short: as far as I can tell this invention is a new catalyst for increasing the efficiency of electrolysis.

But the catalyst is not better than current ones, it's just less toxic (and therefor cheaper). Which, while helpful, is far from groundbreaking.

The electricity can come from anywhere. Saying solar is just a buzzword to get people to click.

Author: astrec
Content:
And whilst I agree a merely competent employee is unlikely to create great software, I hope you're not saying only abrasive, obsessive perfectionists can create great software.

As for the example,

  def f(x,y):
      return x > y
no more captures the intended behaviour of

  lambda x,y: x > y
than "go for nosh" does "go for a nosh." Nuance.

But all this dances around the actual point - that Giles managed to transform himself from wronged to wrongdoer with a single expletive laden harangue, and that this is good for no one, least of all Giles.

Author: adrianwaj
Content:
I just came back from /b/ with a decapitated man's head laying alongside his genitally-dismembered body now seared into my mind. Sounds like a daily hangout for some.

I just posted this to my Friendfeed:

"A good idea is to have a cross-site commenting system such as Disqus that enables both identity-verified and anonymous commenting and comment viewing. This separates commenters into two groups, those who want to be anonymous and those that do not. The system would not be fault-free, but it would promote responsibilty, encourage better commenting and improve user experience without necessitating modding - one's named identity is the moderating factor. It may not be as fun, but would filter out spam, trolls and junk."

Plastic.com has the feature to post a comment as anonymous even whilst logged-in. Trolls would absolutely love this. Also, anonymous comments can be set to hidden.
